G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord may not, directly or indirectly, interfere with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 3, and 20.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Boston Housing Court pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §§ 1, 3, and 20, because this action concerns a residential tenancy and property located within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: As landlord, Defendant is required under Massachusetts law to provide and maintain heat in compliance with the State Sanitary Code.

105 C.M.R. 410.201.proposition: The State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.201, requires landlords to provide heating facilities during the heating season capable of maintaining minimum indoor temperatures in dwelling units.

*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.proposition: Massachusetts law implies in every residential lease a covenant of quiet enjoyment and a warranty of habitability, which includes the duty to provide heat sufficient to comply with the State Sanitary Code and to maintain the premises in a condition fit for human habitation.
*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a separate opinion (concurring in part and dissenting in part), not the majority. Although Justice Quirico agrees that the old no-repair rule should be reconsidered and would imply landlord obligations based on the State Sanitary Code, he expressly criticizes the majority’s broader ‘implied warranty of habitability’ doctrine and prefers a narrower contract-based implication tied to code minimums. Because it is not the controlling opinion and in fact disputes key aspects of the majority’s formulation of an implied warranty of habitability, this passage does not itself establish the proposition that Massachusetts law implies, in every residential lease, both a covenant of quiet enjoyment and a warranty of habitability requiring adequate heat and habitability under the State Sanitary Code. The proposition is grounded in the majority opinion in Hemingway, not this concurrence/dissent.
*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.relevant_excerpt: “I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair….’ … As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards….”}

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts law implies in every residential lease a covenant of quiet enjoyment and a warranty of habitability, which includes the duty to provide heat sufficient to comply with the State Sanitary Code and to maintain the premises in a condition fit for human habitation.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the State Sanitary Code’s requirement that an owner must supply heat and hot water unless a written agreement shifts the fuel obligation to the tenant, and it affirms a breach of the warranty of habitability with some code violations. However, the case does not state or analyze the broader doctrinal point that every Massachusetts residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and an implied warranty of habitability, nor does it expressly tie the heating obligation to those implied covenants as a matter of general Massachusetts law. It applies those concepts rather than articulating the general rule contained in the proposition.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling ‘shall’ supply heat and hot water ‘except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.’ … Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability… The judge properly could have disregarded the minor code violations.”

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Failure to meet Sanitary Code requirements can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly ties habitability, and thus the tenant’s rent and related remedies, to compliance with the State Sanitary Code. It states that a dwelling with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable and that the landlord must at least meet minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes to satisfy its obligations. This makes clear that failure to meet Sanitary Code requirements can constitute a breach of the landlord’s obligations that underlie quiet enjoyment-type protections, including rent abatement.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’… A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for… In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes. Whether the scope of the warranty is broader is an open question.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.proposition: Landlords are strictly liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for substantial interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment, without the need to prove that the landlord acted with malice or bad faith.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly rejects any requirement that a tenant prove the landlord acted with malice or specific intent to interfere with quiet enjoyment, holding that malicious intent is not necessary and that reckless conduct suffices under G.L. c. 186, § 14. However, the court expressly declines to decide whether liability is strictly liable or requires some level of fault short of intent, and instead limits its holding to at least reckless conduct. Because the proposition claims strict liability (no fault requirement at all), the case does not support that broader rule.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.relevant_excerpt: “Our analysis of the language and history of § 14, however, leads us to conclude that malicious intent is not necessary, and that the statute covers, at the least, reckless conduct such as Gem’s. … In sum, we hold that a tenant need not seek a criminal conviction before claiming damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14. Nor must the tenant prove that the landlord intended to interfere with the tenant’s rights, at least as long as the landlord’s conduct was reckless.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: Landlords are strictly liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for substantial interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment, without the need to prove that the landlord acted with malice or bad faith.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses the implied/common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction, not liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It discusses that the landlord’s intent is not controlling and that liability can be based on the natural and probable consequences of the landlord’s conduct, but it does not interpret § 14 or characterize it as imposing strict statutory liability without malice or bad faith. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific statutory proposition stated.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: “Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: A landlord’s failure to make effective repairs to known serious conditions, resulting in continued or repeated loss or insufficiency of essential services, constitutes “interference” within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses what level of landlord fault is required to violate G.L. c. 186, § 14 and confirms that negligent failure to repair known defects can constitute a violation. However, it does not specifically address “continued or repeated loss or insufficiency of essential services,” nor does it define such failures as “interference” in those terms. The case is used here for the general principle that negligent failure to address known conditions can violate § 14, but it does not directly establish the more specific proposition stated.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A landlord’s failure to make effective repairs to known serious conditions, resulting in continued or repeated loss or insufficiency of essential services, constitutes “interference” within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that failure to provide heat—an essential service—constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and that liability turns on the landlord’s conduct (failure to furnish heat), not intent or financial ability. While the case does not explicitly frame the issue in terms of “failure to make effective repairs to known serious conditions,” its reasoning that a landlord’s conduct causing continued lack of heat is an “interference” within § 14 is directly analogous and supportive of the stated proposition.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: The interference with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of her home was substantial, not trivial or de minimis, and persisted through a significant portion of the heating season.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether the plaintiff’s interference with use and enjoyment of her home was substantial and persisted through a significant portion of the heating season. Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth. deals with serious interference from drug activity in common areas and its relation to quiet enjoyment, but it does not discuss anything about the heating season, temperature, or duration of interference tied to heating. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition stated.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. ... There must be a trial to determine what, if any, measures the defendant has taken ... and to determine the seriousness or substantiality of the interference with the tenancies.
